content: The Act titled "Border Sovereignty and Protection Act" mandates the construction of two-layered reinforced fencing along the Southwest border. The Border Sovereignty and Protection Act mandates the construction of two-layered reinforced fencing along 350 miles of the southwest border to gain operational control. The Border Sovereignty and Protection Act requires the construction of two-layered reinforced fencing along 350 miles of the southwest border, separated by a Border Patrol access road. The deadline for completion is one year after the enactment of the act. The Border Sovereignty and Protection Act mandates the construction of two-layered reinforced fencing along 350 miles of the southwest border, with a Border Patrol access road. The Secretary cannot count existing fencing from before April 1, 2009, towards meeting the mileage requirement. Authorization of appropriations is provided for implementing this amendment. The Department of Homeland Security has authority to investigate drug offenses alongside the Department of Justice. Additionally, there is a mandatory minimum sentence for firearms smuggling. The Department of Homeland Security has authority to investigate drug offenses alongside the Department of Justice. There is a mandatory minimum sentence for firearms smuggling, with penalties for smuggling firearms into or out of the United States. The mandatory minimum sentence for firearms smuggling, including trafficking crimes, is not less than 15 years of imprisonment. The eligibility requirements for State Criminal Alien Assistance Program (SCAAP) funding are amended to include that a State or political subdivision cannot enter into a contractual arrangement if they have laws or policies that go against certain immigration laws or prohibit law enforcement officials from gathering information on citizenship or immigration status. SEC. 6. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF INADMISSIBLE ARRIVING ALIENS. Section 235(b)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the inadmissibility of certain arriving aliens in the United States. The officer can order the alien's removal from the United States without further review if they fall under 212(a)(6)(C) or 212(a)(7), unless the alien has been charged with a crime or intends to apply for asylum under section 208. If an alien arriving in the United States or not admitted, and not present continuously for 3 years prior, indicates intent to apply for asylum or fear of persecution, they are referred for an interview by an asylum officer under subparagraph (B) if inadmissible under section 212(a)(6)(C) or 212(a)(7). If an alien arriving in the United States or not admitted indicates intent to apply for asylum or fear of persecution, they are referred for an interview by an asylum officer under subparagraph (B) if the officer determines that the alien has been physically present in the United States for less than 1 year. SEC. 7. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF CRIMINAL ALIENS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for expedited removal of criminal aliens from correctional facilities. The Secretary has the authority to determine deportability and issue removal orders for such aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to expedite the removal of criminal aliens from correctional facilities. Aliens convicted of specific criminal offenses are subject to deportation under the new provisions. Additionally, limitations on injunctive relief are specified in the Act. SEC. 8. MANDATORY EMPLOYMENT AUTHORIZATION VERIFICATION. The text chunk discusses making the Basic Pilot Program permanent and mandating the use of the E-Verify system for verifying employment authorization in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure that a toll-free telephone line is available for verification in the United States. Federal agencies and contractors must use the E-Verify program within one year of the enactment of the Act. Employers with 100 or more employees must comply with the requirements within two years of the Act's enactment. Employers with 30 or more employees have three years to comply. Large employers are those with over 250 employees in the United States. Entities employing 30 or more individuals in the US must comply within three years of the Act's enactment. All employers, regardless of size, must comply within four years. Verification of employment authorization through E-Verify is required within four years of the Act. Employers in the United States must comply with E-Verify requirements to avoid liability for hiring unauthorized aliens. Noncompliance will result in sanctions and violations of immigration laws. Employers in the United States must comply with E-Verify requirements to avoid liability for hiring unauthorized aliens. Violations of immigration laws can result in sanctions if an employer is found to have violated section 274A(a)(1)(A). Employers not immediately subject to the requirement can voluntarily use the E-Verify program to verify employment authorization of new hires or current employees. States cannot prohibit the use of E-Verify for this purpose.
